39279913.review:
Yume Nikki (Diario dei Sogni) è un gioco freeware creato con RPG Maker 2003 e rilasciato nel 2004 
È difficile spiegare a parole i pregi di Yume Nikki e perché negli anni sia diventato un classico, dando vita a centinaia di cloni fanmade e da cui altrettanti giochi indipendenti hanno preso ispirazione.
Il modo migliore per comprenderlo è sicuramente giocarlo, cosa che vi invito caldamente a fare. Il gioco si può completare in meno di due ore, ma dato che la sua caratteristica principale è il disorientamento, le ore che dovrete dedicarci potrebbero aumentare esponenzialmente.

Il gameplay di Yume Nikki consiste SOLO nell'esplorare il mondo dei sogni nei panni di Madotsuki, la protagonista del gioco.
Non ci sono combattimenti, non ci sono dialoghi, non ci sono cutscene, non ci sono sequenze d'azione (mi viene in mente una sola eccezione ma è abbastanza tralasciabile, mi obbligo ad evidenziarla solo per non essere corretto).
Sparsi per il mondo dei sogni, ci sono più di 20 oggetti particolari che spingeranno il giocatore a visitare la maggior parte delle mappe per collezionarli, ognuno di questi oggetti potrà essere "equipaggiato" da Madotsuki in modo da utilizzarne l'effetto attivo corrispondente.
Faccio un esempio per collegarmi ad un altro punto: una volta trovata la Bicicletta, Madotsuki potrà equipaggiarla dal menu degli effetti per muoversi più velocemente, esattamente come in Pokémon.
Madotsuki può utilizzare un solo effetto alla volta.

Tra tutti gli effetti ho citato proprio quello della Bicicletta per dire questo: spostarsi in Yume Nikki richiede molto tempo, Madotsuki è lenta e alcune mappe sono immense, senza punti di riferimento è facile errare per decine di minuti.
La Bicicletta è un buon compromesso, e pur essendo un'esperienza da giocare per la prima volta senza sapere nulla a riguardo, conoscere da subito la locazione di questo effetto è forse l'unica cosa per cui vi consiglio di guardare su Internet.

Il gioco inizia con Madotsuki nella sua piccola camera da letto, provando ad uscire dalla porta lei scuoterà la testa in segno di negazione, mentre è possibile uscire sul balcone, vuoto.
Il diario sulla scrivania permette di salvare la partita (da qui viene il nome del gioco).
Interagendo con la televisione, il giocatore potrà giocare al semplice arcade "NASU".
Presto ci si renderà conto che l'unico altro oggetto della camera con cui poter interagire è il letto, facendolo Madotsuki si infilerà sotto le coperte: dopo una breve dissolvenza si ritroverà sul balcone, questa volta con una musica minacciosa, a sottolineare che ora ci si trova nei sogni.
La differenza è che ora la porta della camera si aprirà, consentendo l'accesso al Nexus, il centro del mondo dei sogni di Madotsuki.
Il Nexus funge da hub che connette alcune delle mappe più importanti del mondo dei sogni, da non scambiare per livelli, il mondo di Yume Nikki non è per niente lineare: infatti entrando in una delle porte nel Nexus si potranno comunque raggiungere molte delle altre mappe connesse al Nexus, formando di fatto un loop.

Il mondo dei sogni è formato dai ricordi e dall'immaginazione della protagonista, esplorarlo è l'unico modo che ha il giocatore per sapere di più su Madotsuki, dato che il gioco è privo di qualsiasi spiegazione o introduzione cinematica.
Yume Nikki è il primo videogioco con questo tipo di storytelling, in cui viene raccontato il passato e il carattere di un personaggio senza utilizzare parole ma mostrandone i sogni e i pensieri, lasciando all'interpretazione del giocatore il resto.
Pur essendo un gioco relativamente breve, Yume Nikki è riuscito a far parlare di sé per più di dieci anni per via dell'elevato numero di simbolismi e elementi apparentemente inspiegabili che i fan hanno utilizzato per teorizzare sul loro significato e sul passato di Madotsuki.

Il design di Yume Nikki è unico, i mondi e i personaggi al suo interno sono tanto caratterizzati quanto surreali, al punto che anche lo stile grafico varia in modo imprevedibile proprio come i sogni della protagonista: alcune sprite sembrano fatte su paint, altre pixel art, altre completamente astratte.
Interagire con un personaggio gli farà emettere un semplice rumore o animazione, altri condurranno Madotsuki in un altro luogo e altri le conferiranno un oggetto: reazioni semplici come queste permetteranno al giocatore di comprendere vagamente cosa rappresenta il personaggio in questione per la protagonista.
Pure le meccaniche di gameplay sono anticonvenzionali: passare da una mappa all'altra raramente avviene tramite una porta, ma ad esempio interagendo con un oggetto leggermente fuori posto.
Yume Nikki riesce a giustificare questo genere di meccaniche poco intuitive grazie al contesto dei sogni, chiedendo al giocatore di sviluppare curiosità e di pensare fuori dagli schemi.

Le tracce della colonna sonora puntano tutto sull'effetto ambientale di sottofondo più che su motivetti orecchiabili, sono generalmente composte da pochissime note ripetute all'infinito che creano un'atmosfera spettrale, surreale, disorientante, racchiudendo appieno lo stile del gioco.
La traccia "Eyeball World" è assurda, la mappa in cui è riprodotta mi turba a distanza di anni e la causa principale è appunto la musica.
"Monochrome World" è la traccia più semplice che io abbia sentito in un videogioco, formata letteralmente da tre suoni e rimane la mia preferita di tutta l'OST.
Non ci sono tracce particolarmente memorabili data la natura "di sottofondo" di esse, forse quella che rompe di più questa regola è "Saving Theme", una fan favourite rifatta e remixata all'infinito.
In generale, l'OST rispecchia appieno la filosofia del gioco: confondere, disorientare e creare un'atmosfera surreale utilizzando elementi semplici.

Yume Nikki è la dimostrazione che l'idea è molto più importante dell'esecuzione.
Il gioco è semplice, anticonvenzionale, grezzo.
Eppure da quando è stato rilasciato, Yume Nikki ha fatto sognare migliaia di giocatori in cerca di un'esperienza alternativa, con i suoi mondi grotteschi, personaggi strani e significati celati per i più curiosi, anche se non sarà mai un videogioco per tutti, non ha mai voluto esserlo.
Con dispiacere, ho dovuto escludere da questa recensione moltissime sfumature e significati del gioco che ricadono nel soggettivo, anche se sono una grande fetta dell'esperienza: Yume Nikki è un gioco evocativo, il suo scopo principale è far riflettere e interpretare i suoi messaggi apparentemente insensati.
Lasciandosi dietro di sé una scia infinita di fangame, Yume Nikki è passato alla storia come il videogioco horror di nicchia più influente di sempre.

-Rikkukun

39279119.review:
Yume Nikki is one of those games that stuck with me for my whole life since I first played it. I frequently recall parts of the game in my mind randomly day by day. It's one of those games you begin to play and you just get sucked into it, before you know it it's been 3 hours and all you've done is walk around in this game. You have to be in the right mindset in this game, it's not a fast game by any means. You have to give it the time and mentallity it demands.
This game should never be played with a walkthrough, the entirety of the game feel is to get lost and lose yourself in the game. It's a game about dreams, it's supposed to be unpredictable and weird, allow the game to do so.
If you enjoy atmospheric horror and surrealism this game is just for you. It has a very good balance of keeping it ominous and creepy without ever getting ridiculous or stale.
As you play you'll fall in love with the odd characters and scenery. It's a cult classic, and many reviere it as one of the best games to come out of RPG Maker. That being said it is still and RPG Maker game; simple in scope and play but effective in setting a feeling without being overbearing.
That all being said Yume Nikki is a game I'll never forget, if you have the time please play through it. It's free and well made.

39272839.review:
(Ignore the playtime; I played the original upload to 100% multiple times as a teenybopper)

The only good walking simulator, and a beautiful accident resulting from the creator uploading a half-finished RPG Maker game to their website. Do not look at spoilers on Youtube or the wiki, at least not until you're tired of finding things on your own.

Yume Nikki is a very strange game. I wouldn't even call it a "game"; it's more of an experience. It's more about taking in the atmosphere and sights than "beating" it. Time to finish is pretty short, but there are tons of random things to find that you will most likely miss on your first playthrough -- it's basically Easter Eggs: The Game.

I think everyone should at least check it out. Depending on who you are, it will either be a beautiful, unique experience that makes you think and feel many things with nary a spoken word or even any explicit narrative, or it might be a waste of your time. The only way to find out is to dive in.

Be wary; dreams are windows into the depths of the mind. There are things down there that may be better left undisturbed...

39271412.review:
One of my favorite games, and the most inspirational game of all time. With an well-executed atmosphere, an overwhelming ambient soundtrack, bizarre graphics, modern gameplay, and a dreaded sense of eldritch emptiness, Yume Nikki has set the baseline standard for RPG Maker games--and 21st-century adventure games in general.

There's more to this than "beating the game" though. Can you find all of the optional scenes and memes? And, in the end, what do you think all these things in this game mean?

39270968.review:
A esta obra la categorizaría como una experiencia psicodelica y completamente unica. 
Aquí no esperes dar disparos o ver explosiones rimbombantes, aca debes llegar focalizado, dejarte llevar y disfrutar de la excelente ambientacion, que si bien, hechandole un primer vistazo rapido puede que no te enganche... pero si das un poquito de tí, podrás darte cuenta que la musica de fondo, los escenarios variopintos  y NPCs descabellados contribuyen rotundamente a creerte el cuento, adentrarte y viajar en el mundo de los sueños de Madotsuki.
Algo que sin duda me llamó la atencion en su tiempo, fue que el juego no te cuenta una historia de forma explicita y que puede llegar a ser muy criptico al momento de darte a conocer algo. No veas esto como algo negativo, sino que tomalo como un gran "plus", ya que a mi juicio resulta una practica muy interesante el hecho de crear tu propia interpretacion, generar tus teorias y validarlas con tus propios fundamentos. (Esto mismo me hizo navegar muchisimo tiempo por internet, leyendo y conociendo puntos de vista de otros jugadores. El lore de este juego puede variar de persona en persona.)
Sin duda un gran videojuego que con su simpleza, puede abarcar temas muy delicados y profundos, como tambien entregarte una experiencia que quizas no obtengas en algun otro título.
Recomendado al 100%

39270759.review: OK, JÁ TAVA NA HORA DESSE JOGO CHEGAR NA STEAM, E EU NEM SEI COMO COMEÇAR, Yume Nikki é um jogo que de certa forma me mudou, e mudou minha maneira de ver certas coisas no mundo, eu quero tentar o máximo não dar spoilers sobre o jogo, apesar de que talvez uma hora ou outra saia algum sem querer, esse jogo não é um jogo fácil de ser descrito em uma simples review, por isso eu extremamente recomendo você jogar, porque Yume Nikki é um experiência sem igual, e eu tenho certeza que até o final do jogo, você no minimo, vai mudar um pouquinho a maneira como você vê as coisas no mundo, nesse review eu vou deixar uma analise e explicação basica sobre o jogo, e tentar descrever o porque ele é tão especial pra mim. Yume Nikki (Diário dos Sonhos) é um jogo que foi criado no RPG Maker 2003, pelo desenvolvedor Kikiyama, a primeira coisa que eu posso dizer sobre Yume Nikki é que ele é um jogo estranho, muito estranho, toda a historia do jogo não passam de teorias, mas eu vou tentar no minimo explicar aqui o que eu acho que o jogo significa, baseado na minha experiência com ele, em Yume Nikki você controla uma garotinha chamada Madotsuki. Madotsuki é uma "Hikikomori" que é uma pessoa isolada, que nunca sai de casa, isso fica claro no momento em que madotsuki se recusa a abrir a porta do seu quarto, o quarto dela é bem simples, tem uma porta que leva a varanda, cujo o cénario muda dependendo da hora do dia, uma televisão, um video-game, onde você pode passar o tempo com um minigame simples, o diário, onde você salva o jogo, e a cama, que você usa pra entrar no mundo dos sonhos,e ai que é o jogo de verdade. Yume Nikki pode ser definido como um "simulador de sonhos" quando você dorme você entra no mundo dos sonhos de Madotsuki, e ao sair pela porta do seu quarto se encontra em um lugar chamado Nexus, com várias outras portas que levam a sonhos diferentes, e dentro desses sonhos tem lugares que te levam pra mais sonhos e assim por diante, o objetivo principal do jogo é coletar todos os "efeitos", são coisas que ao serem coletadas dão habilidades diferentes pra Madotsuki ao serem escolhidos no menu, alguns deles são úteis, como a bicicleta que você usa pra se locomover mais rápido, outros são inúteis e só servem para enfeite, mas pra chegar ao final, trate de pegar todos, certas ações suas podem influenciar o jogo acionando eventos especiais diferentes, que te levam para lugares incomuns e personagens diferentes, mas os sonhos de Madotsuki não são como qualquer outro sonho, são sonhos estranhos, e é ai que entra a parte bizarra de Yume Nikki, em certas partes do jogo você pode encontrar coisas grotescas, assustadoras e esquisitas, nada que possa te deixar com muito medo, mas pode render um susto ou outro, o jogo em si não tem nenhum dialogo, e não conta historia, isso fica a seu criterio interpretar da maneira que você quiser, eu acho que não posso explicar mais do que isso do jogo sem dar spoiler, então eu vou deixar essa parte por aqui. A minha teoria de Yume Nikki é que os sonhos bizarros de Madotsuki são causados por experiências traumaticas que ela já passou, e talvez esse seja o mesmo motivo pelo qual ela se recusa a sair de seu quarto, o tema "acidente" é algo bem presente no jogo, e você vai perceber isso assim que jogar, também tem teorias de que ela possa ser lésbica e tenha vergonha de admitir isso, por causa de uma npc no jogo que ela aparentemente acha bonita ou atrativa. Yume Nikki é um jogo que eu conheço a muito tempo, e é um jogo que me fez parar pra pensar em como nossos sonhos influênciam em nossas vidas, sonhos são representações do nosso subconsciente de eventos pelos quais nós já passamos, e as vezes, eventos pelos quais ainda iremos passar, em um sonho tudo é possivel, e com esforço, você pode controla-los, talvez isso explique a habilidade da Madotsuki poder usar os efeitos apenas no mundo dos sonhos na hora que ela quiser, e também o fato de ela poder acordar a hora que quiser, Yume Nikki vai te fazer refletir sobre vários pontos da sua vida, mas no final, a experiência vai valer a pena. Yume Nikki é um jogo diferente de tudo o que você jogou, e pra 2004, mesmo não tendo bons graficos nem nada disso, a sua proposta era bem a frente de seu tempo, claro que um jogo tão interessante e diferente como esse não passou despercebido pelas pessoas, Yume Nikki serviu de insipiração para muitos outros jogos, sendo eles de RPG maker ou não, e também gerou muitos fangames incriveis a partir da proposta do jogo, como por exemplo Yume 2kki, e o meu favorito, .flow, também são jogos que merecem sua atenção. Yume Nikki é muito mais que um simples jogo de RPG maker, é uma obra prima que vai te fazer refletir muito, vai te assustar em certos momentos, mas vai te dar uma experiência sem igual, Yume Nikki não é o que parece a primeira vista, e é um jogo que representa muito mais, não apenas como jogo, mas em geral, Yume Nikki com certeza é um jogo que merece sua atenção, por mais que você não goste muito de jogos de RPG maker, recomendo que dê uma chance pra Yume Nikki, você vai se surpreender com o que vai ver, e ele vai tomar um bom tempo seu, simplesmente não tem como descrever mais em uma simples review, apenas jogue, vale muito a sua atenção e o seu tempo. Masterpiece/10

39269542.review:
Walking Before It Was Cool

The release of this game on steam gives modern gamers a chance to look at how truly weird the world of Indie gaming was before Kickstarter, Early Access, and the rise of the AAA/Indie dichotomy. Yume Nikki, or Dream Journal in its native japanese, is, if it can be considered anything at all, a game about isolation. There is something existentially unnerving in it's unrelenting oddity, in the way the game provides a tutorial but explains nothing. Games like this just don't exist anymore, and maybe they never did. But there is something compelling and bold in its strangeness, and if any game could be held up as art, it would be this one. For the low price of nothing, it's certainly worth a look.

Not sure if anyone posted this yet, but here goes:
The reason we lost the save music (when played in english) is the filename, it has 1 too many "B"-s.
So (by default), look up the file below:
C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Yume Nikki\yumenikki\Music\BBBBBBBBBB1.MID

Then remove one of the letter Bs, so there's only 9 of them in the filename.
Load up game.
Hear music.
Cry tears of joy.

39267022.review:
One of my all time favoruite games has come to Steam! It's been a few years since I last played it.

The gameplay itself is very simple (I've even seen it be refered to as "walking simulator"). Its almost entierly atmospheric -- and that atmosphere is one of quiet horror, unsettling vibrance, and bittersweet loniless.

It's a very unique experiance, and it's something that's best captured by playing it yourself rather than watching someone else do it. I've often described it to friends as a surrealist horror scavenger hunt.

Don't expect a clear goal, or a clear way to get to it, and when you "win" the game, don't expect a reward. There are many secrets and events in this game as well, many of which are documented online, but I can't help but wonder if any more have been added for the Steam release.

Note: I would also recomend checking out the fangames of the series -- that is, games made in the same style but telling different stories. I recomend .Flow specifically.

Watch our for the toriningen~

39265654.review:
Yume Nikki.... parece un juego cutre y simple y si es verdad es cutre e incluso no tiene "historia" pero lo que destaca no es la jugabilidad ni el contenido si no la experiencia y la exploración con una atmosfera de misterio que produce.El juego es un misterio desde 2004(yo en ese momento aun usaba pañales) no se sabe el significado de este juego, ni lo que representa ni se sabe nada del creador (Kikiyama) ni se sabia si estaba vivo ya que lleva desde 2008 sin información y parece que no dentro de mucho vamos saber algo....Mas de una decada esperando una respuesta que parecia imposible y al parecer, se esta acercando...


El personaje que es el unico que se conoce y que se controla es Madotsuki, una hikkikomori que cuando sueña va a un nexo de puertas que las puertas lleva al Dream World y poco puedes hacer... lo unico que tienes que hacer es explorar y cada mundo tiene un secreto e easter eggs y que en ese sueño puede conducir a otro sueño...Como dije antes el juego no tiene historia, pero es un 96% seguro que los sueños tienen un significado o un acontecimiento que le sucedio a Madotsuki y hay un minijuego en el cuarto.Y diras porque 96% y no 100%? Simple...los sueños en sí, no los haces..si no se hacen depende de lo que hagas...

Si quieres pasarte el juego es 100% obligatorio una guía ya que tienes que encontrar 24 efectos y la mayoria estan extremadamente bien escondidos pero recomiendo que explores primero antes de hacerlo ya que si no conoces nada del tema se pone tenso..




Conoci Yume Nikki el año pasado he oído hablar de el en 2015 pero no conocia el nombre.



Honestamente es mi 4º juego favorito no solo porque me gusta el misterio y el RPG.Si no porque me siento identificado con Madotsuki y Yume Nikki ya que soy... timeless classic. manages to be spooky without a single cheap jumpscare.

39265345.review:
Never thought I'd see this game on here!

[i]Yume Nikki[/i] puts you in the shoes of Madotsuki, a shut-on who spends her days exploring her dreams. Your main objective is to collect effects scattered throughout the dream worlds, some of which help you dive deeper into the surreal landscapes. There’s no dialogue or story beyond finding the effects, so everything is up to interpretation. The glacial pace might turn off some players, but those who are patient enough to search through Madotsuki's dreams will find a uniquely eerie experience.

My only complaint about this release is that the save music is missing—which is a shame, as it’s one of my favorite tracks. D: I hope an update adds it back in soon!

Серьезно, любой из вас будет жалеть. Лучше закройте тему и забудьте, что тут писалось. Я вполне понимаю, что данным сообщением вызову дополнительный интерес, но хочу сразу предостеречь пытливых - стоп. Остальные просто не найдут.

I remember seeing this game a while back due to a clip showing the uboa easter egg. After seeing that clip i become more interested with this game. I watched a youtuber by the name of Jordan Underneath go into detail about his experience with Yume Nikki and became even more intrigued. The only problem being was that i didnt have the time to play it and that i didnt know where to find it. Luckily it was relased yesterday on Steam. 

There isnt really a main goal in Yume Nikki other than to explore the dream words. By exploring these dream worlds you will uncover some pretty werid stuff an example being some werid purple ghosts lurking in a forest. One other thing you may find when exploring are various diffrent items that may alter your apparence or travel around faster. 


This game probbly isnt for everyone but id recommend it because its a very intresting experience.

39263782.review:
Oh man. There are no words to describe how much I adore this game. Way back when the Uboa event was literally everywhere on the internet, where that face was seen all over everything, did I first hear about this game. 
Everything about this game is strange, and every aspect means something different per person. Creepy, enchanting, thrilling, whatever. Yume Nikki is an experience that deserves to be had. 
Whether you want to explore and find everything yourself, or you want to follow a guide online and do it that way, maybe a combination of both, Yume Nikki will give you experiences you won't forget. 
Even if you want to.
This game is mostly about speculation, finding your own meaning to the way the main character lives her life. The things she might have experienced, the thoughts she has. 
I can't really say anything without giving something away, so I'll just say, play it. You won't regret it.

39263259.review: A great surrealistic exploration game about dream worlds with morbid visuals that come in all sorts of art styles.

39262947.review:
Juegazo!.
Desde el principio te muestra un ambiente atrapante que pareciera que quiere mostrarte mas, solo que, realmente no dejara que sepas mas.
Cada paso generara mas teorias y conexiones en tu cabeza que realmente son el gran plus del juego, es el propio juego que juega contigo. 
Los secretos son realmente dificiles de encontrar y muy sorprendentes, pareciera que no llegas a ninguna parte y PAM algo nuevo que no esperabas ver o un detalle que habias pasado por alto.
Un juego que te hara pensar mucho mas de lo que te muestra y eso lo hace completamente divertido e interesante.

39262914.review:
Este juego hace me deprima.
Pero en una buena manera. Es como llorar sin lagrimas~
Es un escape, otra realidad. Un lugar donde puedes andar y perderte. 
Hace años conozco este juego y verlo aqui me hace feliz.

Solo queda esperar ese nuevo proyecto y saber si realmente kikiyama esta envuelto en todo esto, lo cual dudo, Probablemente ya murio o no le importa y alguien tomo derechos sobre Yume Nikki.
Pero hey, si es un super proyecto fan á lá Yume 2kki entonces esta bien. Pero eh eh eh.... que sea gratis. 
No pueden capitalizar en Yume Nikki. A Yume Nikki no se le toca.

Anyway.
A pesar de que marco este juego como Recomendado debo decir que no lo recomiendo para cualquier persona. Muchas personas lo van a encontrar aburrido, muchas de las cosas no tienen sentido y muchas areas son secretas y solo las hallas por suerte. Recomendaria no usar un Walkthrough, si realmente quieres expermentar este juego debes "vivirlo" y perderte completamente en el. Si eres impaciente como yo, ok. Una guia puede ayudarte, solo busca como llegar a los efectos, en texto sin imagenes o te perderas toda la sorpresa.

Por otro lado, Yo siendo fan desde años de este juego tiendo a mostrarselo a todos mis amigos y... simplemente es un clasico... Es Yume Nikki. Un juego que los normies no conocen pero que sea como sea ha influenciado muchisimos juegos futuros. Es el juego no-conocido más famoso de todos.

39262441.review:
I have the high score on Nasu. Therefore I am God at this game.
6000/100, would Eggplant again. How many eggplants can you eat?

(Also something about Madotsuki possibly being an alien experimentation if you've read the manga!)

I love this game. Even if it's missing some sfx. (WTH devs?) You can easily fix this....... (with some fileplay.)

All in all, most people who have this game have already played it/beaten it/know the ending. So if you're one of these people, you know what you're in for.

If you're new to the game...........

This is for patient people. This is NOT an action game. This is a game to play leisurely, patiently, and most importantly, inquisitively.

There's a lot to think over. You will miss out on so much by just trying to rush the effects and using some guide to find them all.

Take it easy. The game's not going anywhere.

39262399.review: The original walking simulator, except good.

39262002.review:
One of the only games that justifies the medium in a substantial way, and one that influenced a large swath of the current generation of independent game makers. Not recommended if you hate exploration based games, highly recommended if you'd like to see the potential for video games to be auteristic exploration of personal worlds.

There really isn't much of a way for a game like Yume Nikki to age negatively except for being unable to perform on newer software. At the moment that shouldn't be too much of an issue, so this Steam release isn't really warranted because you can already download it for free off the internet. I can't recommend this port because the changes made to the game only take away from the experience rather than enhance it (albeit only very slightly.) Just download the original RPG maker game if you're interested and haven't already played it at this point.

39261564.review: Un RPG tan misterioso, que hasta el dia de hoy, luego de tantos años... seguimos sin saber que es lo que nos quiere mostrar y eso en realidad es lo maravilloso de este juego. Tantas teorias, historias, especulaciones que intentan explicar lo que ocurre aqui pero no nos han confimado nada. El que juega este titulazo, tendra diferentes explicaciones de lo que pasa... pero eso es lo que llama la atencion, la gran variedad de cosas que te permiten interpretarlo de 1 millon de formas (y más). Algunas veces te perturbará... te sentirás incomodo... o directamente te dará miedo, pero creeme que es una experiencia fascinante.

39258626.review:
まさかSteamで、ウボァさんや、キュッキュ君や、センチメンタル小室マイケル坂本ダダ先生と、再開できる日が来るとは…

ゆめにっき以前のRPGツクール作品といえば、レベル上げやザコ敵狩りといった、お約束のようなものがあったのですが、そういった概念を全部ぶっ壊してしまったすごい作品です。

悪夢の中をさまよう感じを再現したゲームとして、これほどよく出来た作品はなかなかないと思います。しかもフリーゲームで無料！

何年も前に最初にプレイした時、ゲームを始めると同時に、わけのわからない世界に放り出されて、何をしたらいいのかすらわからず、あっちこっち行ったり来たりしてる間に、床に散乱する目玉や血のりや、うねうね動くアステカ風の背景に、「うわあああ…」と気持ち悪くなって、寝込んでしまったのも今となってはいい思い出です。

主人公の女の子の名前が、「窓付き」というネーミングセンスの時点で、ただものではない雰囲気があるゲームですが、ほうちょう片手に異世界生物をぐさぐさ刺してる勇姿を見ると、「サイコパスようじょつよい…」と、窓付きちゃんの戦闘力に対して尊敬の念すら湧いてきます。

窓付きちゃんは、かえるになったり、なまくびになったり、のっぺらぼうになったり、キツネやタヌキ以上の変身能力があって、ときどき「本当にこの子人間なの？」と疑問もわいてきますが、「まあ、そういうものだからしょうがない…」と、細かいことは気にならなくなって、性格がおおらかになります。

あと「じてんしゃ」というアイテムがあるのですが、移動速度が上がる有用な装備ですが、異常なエフェクト群のなかで、まともなものはこれしかないので、取得した途端に初期のポケモンをやってる感じになって、「あっ、これホラーゲームじゃなくて、RPGだったんだ…」って正気に戻る瞬間が面白いです。

日本のフリーゲームの中でも、特異なポジションにある本作ですが、Steamでの配信により、海外のかたがどういった感想を持たれるのか、とても楽しみにしています！

39251322.review: I'm so glad this game is finally available on Steam. There isn't much to say about the game as there isn't really a whole lot to do in the game. The art direction is really strong, and considering how intricate and open the game is you could probably explore the game world for hours and still miss something. You'll spend most of your play time wandering the bizarre worlds via the hub world doors. There you might find items that give you access to abilities and transformations, most of which are cosmetic or just detrimental to you. There isn't any aim, or any obvious aim at least, you're pretty much just left to explore at your own pace. This game is fantastic first time playing, you'll almost definitely get lost and maybe even bored at times, but the next big thing you stumble across always makes it worth it. To talk too much about what exactly it is you see and experience in the game would ruin it, as discovery is where the game succeeds best. This game isn't perfect by any means despite how much I might like it. Your character is REALLY slow making exploration tedious at times, especially when trying to find something new. The music is REALLY repetitive with most songs being about 6 seconds in length and just infinitely looping. This game isn't for everyone, and people who enjoy this sort of thing should recognise it at first glance. If this game interests you, don't hesitate to finally play it, there's really nothing else like it.

39250832.review:
As a *big* enthusiast of the exploration component in games this is one of my reference titles when talking about the wonders of this particular element and how it can deliver experiences in ways that combat or storytelling can't.

I'd refrain from calling the game "weird", "strange", "surreal" or any other thing that might come to mind. I really do not believe it was made to fit into a category: go back 13-ish years in time and try to see if there were many similar games like this. It certainly inspired lots of games after it, but this is such a game. Many works of art follow a current, but only few create the current. This is such a work of art.

As someone who has played the game back to back and has known it for more than 10 years already, yes, I do reccomend this game *very* much, and even more if you are passionately invested in videogames, so that you may appreciate it far more than those who just come for the freakouts and goosebumps.

39249541.review:
It's still Yume Nikki. Still a grand ol' time, though I think I'm just saying that because of nostalgia.
There's a lot of text differences from what I remember playing Back In The Day (EX: flute -> whistle, buyobuyo -> squish squish, severed head -> talking head, diary (as the load option) -> dream diary), but those don't affect your overall gameplay experience. However, the save music is no longer in the game, and I am very disappointed because that was arguably one of the best tracks in the game. I don't understand why that song was removed from the Steam version of the game. I still recommend the game just because the gameplay hasn't been changed, so it's still a good game. Still gonna be disappointed about removing music, though.

All in all, I'd recommend getting this game.

39248860.review:
The game's title translates to "Dream Diary."

Well. I mean. This cult classic is exactly what it sounds like. You go through the wild dreams of the protagonist, Madotsuki, and look for "effects" which either affects you or the environment around you.

Don't expect to fight any monsters. This game is first and foremost an exploration game. Sure, you can grab all the "effects" and end it all, but this game is meant to be fully explored and fully interpreted in whichever way the player desires.

The game might seem a bit creepy at first. That's because it originated in Japan. Don't worry. The game doesn't bite! Just dive in without any knowledge. It's best played that way.

this game isn't going to be for everyone. i can definitely see how this game is boring to most people.
personally, i love this game. i love the gameplay, the visuals, and the music. it doesn't get boring for me.

the original english translation, in my opinion, is better than this one however. some of the translations in this version don't feel right, but it's not too bad.
some of the original audio doesn't play, like the save screen music, but it doesn't change the gameplay.

the thing i like most about this is that it's like an update from kikiyama, and now we know he/she is still active. (unless this wasn't uploaded by kikiyama and the upcoming project isn't official either)

i'd recommend this game to anyone who likes surreal atmosphere and mystery. there isn't story behind this game, and what it has going for it are its odd visuals. it's kind of like LSD dream emulator in a way.

39248168.review: Yume Nikki is classic Rpg , and one of the best ones ever made. Its a Surreal experience that cant be put into words. There's barely any dialogue in Yume Nikki, but instead a story is told by each area you explore in the game. This leaves the true plot of the game up for interpretation, and allows everyone to have their own ideas of what the game is truly about. getting lost in each area can tedious at times, but this is easily made up for by the feeling of wonder that comes from finally finding something new. Yume Nikki is a must-play that everyone should experience at one point.

39248015.review:
I really wish I had not played the 3D fangame of this.

I would recommend playing that instead if you want a casual playthrough, since it adds into the atmosphere and the dream worlds are bigger and better, and you don't have to be walking in a straight line for 10 minutes to find the effects, since you can actually >explore< the 3D worlds and it gives you an objective and somewhat of an ending/reward without spending more than 1 hour on it.

This version does not only require your time, but also requires you to be interested on it so you can make actual progress. The description is kind of misleading since it classifies itself as just a "walking simulator", but there's more into it other than just walking around, and you will never know unless you start looking at the small details and begin trying different effects on different places/characters.

This is still a nice play, but for me, my experience is kind of ruined because of the 3D version.

Play this version for lore depth, and play the 3D version for casual fun (that I believe it's what most of the downvoters of this game were expecting to get).

39245536.review:
I'm super glad this game made it to Steam as it is a wonderful game that I played back in highschool(but never beat); but now that it has I feel the need to voice some concerns.

The visuals in this game are very bright color wise; and change VERY often. Whether it be a bright red or randomly colored worlds that blink they all are eye-straining; making it so that I can only play for 10 minutes or so before I have to take a break or else I'll get a headache. 

Along with this such bright lights could very easily trigger someone's epilepsy; and this coming from someone with a light version of epilepsy as the game only currently gives me headaches if I play for too long; and if I get this then imagine someone jumping into this game with severe elipepsy.

Because of this I strongly suggest the creator of this game add a warning for such visually bright things [b]AT LEAST[/b] on the store page; and hopefully in game as there is so such thing anywhere as of yet. Granted, this game did just get released in Steam but even so this severely needs to be an addition to the game or store page.

39245506.review:
Note: Please play through this game blindly. I won't include spoilers in my review, but other reviews might.

Yume Nikki is an adventure game made in RPGmaker in which you explore Madotsuki's surreal dream worlds. The goal is to seek out and acquire all 24 'Effects'. Some effects change Madotsuki's appearence while others allow you to use their abilities to progress through the dream world. I can't state how much I adore this game and hope you enjoy it just as much as I did the first time I blindly played it through years ago.

39244702.review:
I love Yume Nikki - it’s one of the games that has inspired me and shaped my interests for sure. It definitely can come across as just a mindless exploration game with not much to do except for collecting effects, but there's a lot hidden within the game. I recommend taking the time to experiment with each effect and the npcs, and how they react to each other. 39244413.review:
Oh, Yume Nikki... where to start with this one. First, let me apologize for this essay of a review; I really don’t know if I can properly express my feelings otherwise. Also, my hours on Steam are not accurate of my play time, as I played this game plenty off of Steam. With that out of the way, Yume Nikki is one of those games that I absolutely love the hell out of, but usually sounds like a bad game when I try to put it into words for people. Basically, Yume Nikki is a walking simulator where you wander in no particular direction to find some items, called effects. Most of these items are useless, and only change how your character looks. It's pretty easy to see why people can dislike this game; with no direction and no real goal, it can come off as boring and can make people question why they're even playing.

So why do I like this game so much?

The atmosphere of this game is what makes it so magical. Right away, it gives off a strange, eerie vibe, and as you play and explore more it can give off a more unsettling feeling and can sometimes become slightly disturbing. The soundtrack is almost entirely short repeating rhythms with no real melody, which really complements the atmosphere of the game. The vast openness of the world and freedom to explore tops it all off, sending you in no particular direction to explore. The world is large and the different areas within it are all unique. From the sewers, dark and creepy, to the snow world, bright and cheerful, each area has its own feeling. Exploring the world is fun and rewarding, just for the sake of seeing everything the game has to offer. Gathering all of the effects is the primary goal, sure, but experiencing and interacting with the other features hidden within the game was my favourite part. Walk into the first door on your left, the forest area, to see what I mean. There's also special objects or characters you can interact with that cause something to happen, often called "events" by fans. For example, the infamous [spoiler] Uboa event which you get by flicking on and off the Poniko's light switch [/spoiler].
I'll admit I got lost and confused at some points, and had to look up maps. If you feel the same while playing, there's no shame in checking out a map online to try and check your bearings. You can find a list of all the areas and their maps [url=yumenikki.wikia.com/wiki/List_of_Locations] on the wiki[/url]. I've heard that the Steam port isn't the best, with some glitches and crashes, but I didn’t experience any so far. I’ll update this review if I do.

Yume Nikki is probably one of my all-time favourite games because of everything I just said, but again it's definitely not for everybody. Some people end up not liking the atmosphere, some people can’t get over the lack of a clear point to the game. But hey, it's a free game, takes up basically no drive space, and isn't demanding. So why not give it a shot? You might end up falling in love with it like I have.

39242404.review:
For awhile now, this has been one of my favorite little videogame gems. There are few games that leave a mark as unique as Yume Nikki. I have rarely played a game as strange and as facinating as this, and played this roughly around 2011. The community is a testament to its impact on players over the years, and has survived for over a decade to have a upcomming sequel. Enough about that though, what is Yume Nikki?

Yume Nikki is an Indie "horror" game, created by Kikiyama using Rpg maker. I say "horror" because its has a more unique take than typical genre standards. It is a little spooky though. But it relies mostly on you and your exploration of the dream world. Some places are unnerving, others are plesant, others i would rather not go back to, and some are even really relaxing. Atmosphere is a major contributer to the areas in the game. And yes this does have a pretty good soundtrack, even some of the fan remixes. The basic premise is you are a hikikomori (recluse) girl name Madotsuki and you explore her dreams in a dream world. Each world has a few items hidden around known as "effects" that do specific things like turn you into a frog, give you a bicycle, even just have longer hair. There are 24 in all. Some are important, most just to have fun with. Which sounds really boring but i promise exploring these worlds is the best part about this game. 

Spending time just roaming around into random parts of the dream world exploring is where this game shines. Each world has its own door, some areas can only be accessed by certain doors. Some are even connected to each other. There really isn't any dialogue throughout the game, mostly its up to you to interpret and explore these worlds. Almost like a create your own adventure book.

In conclusion, this is a wonderfull little gem. Its not a game for everyone, and its basically a walking simulator with atmosphere. Even if you don't like this game in the end, its one of those memorable and unique games worth playing that you can't really find anywhere else. Also play this game as blind as possible, a map might come in handy later but limit to only that. It could spoil some areas or moments along with the fun of just randomly stumbling onto areas and npc's. Otherwise have fun exploring Yume Nikki!

39242298.review:
While it's certainly not a game for everyone, Yume Nikki provides an experience unlike any other. While there are some creepy elements, it's not a horror game per se, the overall atmosphere of the game might make you feel uneasy, but it's the sense of lonesomeness you get that really stands out above all else. While the lack of any dialogue makes even the smallest interaction with NPCs meaningful, it still allows the game to keep its sense of isolation, even within the company of other characters. Many areas of the game take heavy inspiration from traditional Paracas art (similar to Aztec art), the obscurity of which, helps create the alien feeling to the dreamscapes, that, while unfamiliar, remain thematically consistent.

There's a reason Yume Nikki became the cult classic it did, it's an experience that can't be replicated, and one that I highly reccomend.

39242294.review: I don't want to say anything without necessarily overinflating Yume Nikki's worth, but it really is the beginning of all those RPG maker games that have become so popular over the years. Mysterious, ambient, drenched in speculation, Yume Nikki is equal parts melancholic and fever dream material.

39242271.review:
[h1]It finally happened.[/h1]

Never, in a million years, I thought i'd ever be saying this. I always thought it would just be a silly pipe dream that would never happen. It's insane considering how long i've waited for a return of this game, and how long i've been a big fan of it. It all just seemed like a dream in itself. Considering this in the context of the game, it's quite ironic but...

[b]Yume Nikki was released on Steam, at long last.[/b] 

Considering I did a serious review for OneShot and I became a much better writer since then, I'm going to discuss this game at great lengths and tell you why you should play this. It's a truely amazing game.

[h1]CrocoKid's Friendly Warning:[/h1]

[b]SPOILERS. AHEAD. It is absolutely best to play Yume Nikki blind! Also, don't look up guides or walkthroughs![/b]

[h1]The Story of Yume Nikki[/h1]
Story? What story!? Hah! As if this game would ever make any sort of sense.

Actually, no, because if you look closer, Yume Nikki isn't just a 'weird and surreal exploration game'. Sure, it's full of many odd, surreal, and downright disturbing and scary setpieces, but if you take into consideration all the things the game is showing you, things begin to make a lot more sense. If you take the time to look at all the infinitesimal details in the game, the story reveals begins to slowly unravel itself. To me, Yume Nikki is a sort-of character study for our titular daydreamer, Madotsuki.

Madotsuki is a seemingly normal young girl living in an apartment who refuses to leave her room. Notice though; If you were to try to leave the room, you'd learn that she refuses to leave her room. It SEEMS like a pointless detail, but it's all the more important. From this, we gather a few possiblities of why she's in her room, all alone.

1. She could've been locked in there by her parents.
2. She could be a hikikomori, a japanese term used for reclusive young adults who shut themselves away from society.
3. The most boring option, she just doesn't want to leave her room.

This seemingly small detail opens up new possiblities, and opens up more questions. "Why did her parents lock her in there?" or "What caused her to become a Hikikomori?" Once you fall asleep, you begin to learn even more then you ever thought you'd learn about a seemingly normal girl. Madotsuki is perhaps one of the deepest characters ever, because if you think of all the details you see in the game, you come up with theories, and you begin to piece your own form of the very vague narrative of Yume Nikki.

Most of the subtle narrative is shown through symbolism; There are definitely themes of death, murder, rape, pregnancy, isolation, loneliness, and sadness all throughout this game. Shitai-san, the man who got ran over by a car, Madotsuki seemingly and willingly stabbing possibly innocent NPCs throughout the game (but done by player choice), [spoiler] The infamous monster Uboa that might be seemingly implying that Madotsuki is possibly pregnant and possibly thinking of an abortion... [/spoiler]

You might find a child wearing a snow hat and a brown-ish red scarf in a world of blocks who is invisible. That is, until you try to use the Stoplight effect, and notice that the girl fully reveals herself. Could this be an implication that Madotsuki was very shy around new people? Think about it. This character (when revealed) not only slightly resembles Madotsuki, but only reveals itself with a special effect. Could this mean she wanted to hide away from other kids?

You may note while climbing a giant staircase that two men are falling from the sky for seemingly no reason. Again, think of the vague story. "Is Madotsuki afraid of heights?" "Who are those two men?" The game is chock full of subtle narrative, and if you take the time to really analyze what makes this plot so interesting, it begins to make a lot more sense.

In Madotsuki's 'dream world', you will find many different 'effects'. The 'goal' of the game is to find all 24 effects. These effects help you access new areas, trigger an event, or just be there to be silly. Once you've gathered all 24 effects and set them down in the Nexus, a room with 12 doors leading to different dream worlds, [spoiler] you can view the ending after waking up. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] Madotsuki wakes up to find a staircase on her balcony for seemingly no reason. She eventually climbs up, and jumps off it, ending her life in a bloody splatter. The implications of this are quite strong. While we may not know what exactly made Madotsuki commit suicide at the end of the game, there's plenty of possible reasons. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] 1. She had explored all that her dreams had to offer, her 'escape', and jumped off because she was still locked in her room. [/spoiler]
[spoiler] 2. She was depressed and wanted solace. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] When two monsters from her dreams appear next to the bloody splatter, this might also indicate something; Was Madotsuki dreaming within a dream? Did she jump off to wake up from the nightmare or did she truely die? [/spoiler]

The game never gives you any direct answers, and that's what makes it so brilliant. You have to decipher what the plot means to you on your own. You're given pieces to the puzzle, you just have to stick them in place.


[h1] The Music [/h1]
The music of Yume Nikki is quite different from most games. It's very ambient, dark, and foreboding, while at times also being comforting and deceptively happy. Interestingly, most of the music consists of 6 - 10 second loops, but they seem to never get annoying as they seem to lack melody and at times doesn't even sound like music. It creates a very hypnotic and sleepy atmosphere. A lot of the music in the game I could very easily fall asleep to. Quite ironic, considering the game is about dreams.

My favorite song in the game is a tossup; I absolutely love the music that plays on The Docks, the Witch's Flight event, The Aztec Rave Monkey (it's a thing trust me), and I adore the simplistic and melancholy tunes that play when you save the game and when you finish the game.

[h1] The Artstyle [/h1]
My personal favorite thing about the game is the incredibly nice artstyle. It feels very "EarthBound-esque." Infact, on the subject of EarthBound, there's an area that is a homage to the first EarthBound game, MOTHER. The game's artstyle is consistent in it's quality. It stays 16-bit throughout most of the game, but at points the game gets a radically different artstyle and looks almost photo-realistic, which is interesting considering how unpredictable dreams in real life can be.

I love Madotsuki's character design, too. She has a cute sweater, her eyes are always closed, and... d'aww.. She's just so cute!

[h1] The Gameplay and Controls [/h1]
In Yume Nikki, the entire point of the game is to just explore Madotsuki's dream world. That's quite literally it, you're just there to explore aimlessly and see what kind of thing you'll find. The gameplay is certainly hypnotic and is especially interesting considering it was made in RPG Maker 2003, and yet it barely features any form of RPG elements.

 You press the Z/Enter key to interact with objects, trigger certain events, and other miscellanous things. You move with the Arrow keys, and you press the 1 key to do a special action. Pressing the 9 key wakes up Madotsuki, where you can save your game. Pressing 5 in the Nexus lets you drop the currently selected effect [spoiler] which allows you to see the ending once all 24 effects are dropped in the Nexus. [/spoiler]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Yume Nikki is a wonderous game. I think that it's one of the most interesting games to ever come out, and the fact that there is so much to see and do in the game is great fun in itself. There are some horror elements, and the game can make you very, very uncomfortable at points, and if you're not into that it might turn you off, but overall, the game is utterly fantastic.

[h1]CrocoKid's Score[/h1]

9.7/10

39242209.review:
I have extensively played this game years ago, when it was an almost unknown indie game, by a mysterious creator known as KIKIYAMA. 

This game is an adventure in the dream world of Madotsuki, a girl you know nothing about. You explore her dreams, find things called "Effects" and collect them.
Gameplay wise it's as barebone as it can be: it's mostly just walking around exploring. There is no "lore" or anything like this. No "encounters" or fights. 
There is only your interpretations and theories about what you see. And that's the main point of the game.

I believe it's not a game that can be enjoyed by everyone, but you should still give it a shot. Explore a mysterious and surreal dream world to collect all the Effects, and then it's up to you to connect the dream worlds to some idea on who Madotsuki is. [spoiler] Or where she will go...[/spoiler]
Be sure to play it with lights off. The immersion this game provides is beautiful.

Also, don't play with the lightswitch too much.



Some locations may be tedious to find, but since this game has been around from more than 10 years it has an actually big fan community behind, with wikis and walkthroughs.
This game has so much fans there are also some unofficial spinoffs made by them; the most famous being Yume 2kki and .flow. Be sure to check them out if you enjoy Yume Nikki!

Yume Nikki is a masterpiece. I can't say anything less about it.
You're thrust into a cold, dark world filled with esoteric horrors like noone has ever seen before. 39241260.review:
To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Yume Nikki. The humour is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of DREAMING most of the jokes will go over a typical playerhead. There’s also UBOA nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they’re not just funny- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Yume Nikki truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn’t appreciate, for instance, the humour in Uboa’s existential catchphrase “あああああああ,” which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev’s Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I’m smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Kikiyama’s genius wit unfolds itself on their computer screens. What fools.. how I pity them. 😂

And yes, by the way, i DO have a Yume Nikki tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It’s for the ladies’ eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they’re within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothin personnel kid 😎

39240817.review:
I need to start off by saying that I'm really glad to see this game on Steam, even years after its initial release.
I've played (and finished many times) Yume Nikki long ago, yet this game still stuck with me.

If you are reading this and never played the game, I would definitely recommend that you try it.
While many other creators made fangames of Yume Nikki or tried imitating its style, the original game is truly a unique experience.
If you are looking for an atmospheric, creepy, odd, psychedelic game where you hunt for objects while strolling into unfamiliar environments and mazes, then this game is for you.
This game is also quite slow-paced. You really need to take your time and explore all the maps to reach the end of the game. It can get a bit frustrating sometimes, but wandering aimlessely is quite a big part of Yume Nikki.

And if you already played the game, and enjoy darker themes, I highly recommend that you play dotFLOW. It's an amazing fangame.

I really hope to see more of Kikiyama's work !

(Sidenote : This game contains imagery and thematics that may disturb some people. Also, take care if you're sensitive to flashing lights. -  Btw English isn't my mother tongue, and I never ever review games so sorry if all of this sounds lame lol)

39240392.review:
Yume Nikki is a pioneer of its genre, and still holds up to this day, despite its creator going off the grid years ago. The extent to which it pushed the tools that forged it is impressive even by the standards of a decade later, and the effort all shows in the game's atmosphere and imagery. It's far from a polished diamond: not having features such as a map to aid in traversing openly looping landscapes is probably the biggest turnoff new players might cite, along with some of the RNG scripted events that have come to be seen as the game's most popular. Despite the unbuffed edges, however, the game glows bright, unapologetically showing the beauty, ugliness, and everything in between inside the mind of a girl who the player can come to know in a way few other characters have been, despite her not saying a word.

There are many valid reasons to dislike walking simulators, but to anyone willing to stomach the few lackluster mechanical elements of the genre, a mindfuck awaits, the likes of which you've never seen before.

You [i]can't really call it a Game,[/i] more like a piece of Art or an Experience and that's exactly why it is so perfect in my opinion. The confusion as to what the game really means by the lack of guidence to the player spawned the Culture that's around it today. Free to interpret the Game it set the perfect Playground for Fan-created Content which made the game even better. 

[b]It still is Fun nonetheless, You search in a Giant Maze existing in your Dreams for Objects called "Effects" which change your appearance and give you a some kind of Ability, trying to find every single one and see the Ending. Its exploratin-heavy, has zero Dialogue, and much to see and Experience (that also can make zero Sense).[/b]
[i]The Art and Soundtrack is also reaaaallly good.[/i]

This Game exposed me very early to Internet Culture. I first saw it in a Video and instantly fell in love with the Game. Since then I have played it countless of times, including the many Fangames and Normal Games it inspired.
[spoiler]The Culture showed me how inspiring and creative people like Kikiyama can be with using simple methods like RPGMaker but still make this kind of Art while dealing with such sensitive topics like Isolation, Death, Dreams and much more, wether it is Japanese, European or American which show me wonderful Creations like this one. These People manage to portray such Complex Psychological Emotions of the Human Brain in a Beatiful Way that i deeply feel conected with becaues it represents these in a easy but effective way.[/spoiler]

Even tough it has it's fair share of Flaws it still is something that I think should be just admired for what it is. People may call it boring or pretentious and that's perfectly fine because I relate to it in a more Personal Way than Gameplay-wise and that can hugely differ from Person to Person.

I really hope I don't sound too exaggerated but seeing this favorite Videogame of mine get revived with so much Ambition just makes me extremely Happy.

Parte da un presupposto interessante, ovvero seguire una hikikomori nei propri sogni. E per sogni intendiamo quelli che si fanno dormendo, in fase REM e non REM, e che per questo possono avere un filo logico o apparire del tutto insensati, come tutti noi avremo sperimentato.
Tuttavia, tolto il presupposto, il gioco si presenta come una sorta di tedioso walk simulator che a me, personalmente, non trasmette proprio nulla.

Intorno a questo titolo si è poi scatenata nel tempo tutta una serie di teorie da parte di fan e/o youtubers che si son lanciati in più o meno improbabili voli pindarici. Un po' come quando un "artista" macchia una tela con la punta del pennello lasciando una pallino rosso su sfondo bianco, ed i critici si scervellano a trovargli 1000 profondi e diversi significati.

Io l'ho provato per curiosità perchè è considerato un titolo "storico" nel panorama indie.
Forse, se realizzato in modo diverso - magari non in rpgmaker, ma anche solo in 2d con dei fondali ben disegnati, più evocativi -  potrebbe risultare un buon titolo nel suo genere.

39238716.review:
Despite the gameplay amounting to little more than wandering around aimlessly, Yume Nikki is one of the most bizarre and impactful games I've ever played. It's not a masterpiece of game design or gameplay, but what it *does* accomplish cannot be understated. The unsettling, surreal dream world of Yume Nikki will remain in your mind as you wonder how an RPG Maker game with 16-bit graphics has managed to create one of the most unforgettable atmospheres a video game has to offer.

My recommendation is to play Yume Nikki for as long as you possibly can before feeling like you absolutely can't make any more progress, and then to use a spoiler-free guide to finish the rest of the game. The game is massive, so don't give up right after you get stuck for the first time. Or fifth time.

Is Yume Nikki a good "game"? Almost all existing conventions would say it's not. But forget about what you think video games "should" be. Yume Nikki is an irreplaceable experience that I will never forget. Put on some headphones and let Madotsuki's melancholy dreams take you away.

Yume nikki no es como cualquier otro juego, no hay enemigos en cada esquina, no hay giros de trama importantes que impacten al usuario, no hay un argumento real y sólido...sin embargo, con solo imagenes y pequeños sonidos puede atrapar al jugador en su gran gran mundo. Sin embargo, toda la experiencia que se genera al jugarlo es...casi magia, juega con las emociones con tan poco...algo que muchos consideran tan "simple" ha creado momentos inolvidables, no solo para mi, si no para muchas personas más...

39237714.review:
My lovely, teenager-years game. 
When I was going through a heavy depression, Madotsuki's world merged with mine and I grew infatuated with it.

I wanted to understand it, and so I kept exploring her dreams with only the hardest parts, sometimes not knowing where to go I grew impatient and got myself some assistance.

I've wished to make my own kind of dream diary ever since, and thus my curiousity for the darkness and weirdness within me grew stronger than my fears.

It may sound cliche, since it is. The game won't be as emotional and emerging when replaying it, but it was a great game to play in a moment of my youth. If exploring is something you like, this game is for you. 

If you don't enjoy the hard parts of it, search up guides for it. It's better to get the full experience, rather than leaving it unfinished just because of some gamers pride or something.

39237053.review:
Yume Nikki doesn't feel like a game, or even a walking simulator. Yume Nikki feels like a window. It feels like something from a creepypasta, this odd pixelated game with its own stubborn sense of dream logic. It is indifferent towards you and how you feel about it. It's meditative, horrible, peaceful, heartbreaking. It'll give you a heart attack. It'll let you fly--sometimes on a broomstick, sometimes without one.

The game concerns a girl named Madotsuki. She never leaves her room. All she does is play a video game, write in her dream diary, and go to sleep to explore her own strange dreams.

I can't remember the first time I played it. It was almost ten years ago, certainly. All I know is that the game immediately left an impression on me. Yume Nikki is difficult in many, many ways, and it's absolutely not for everyone. Too many of the game's dream worlds are unfocused, leaving you to wander aimlessly in search of effects.

Frankly, I would recommend having a guide handy, if only to find the bicycle and the knife so you can deal more easily with the bizarre, occasionally long-winded level design.

That being said, the vastness and the bleakness of the levels have positive effects. There's a sense of being overwhelmed by these fantasies, stumbling from dream to dream, never quite knowing what the "rules" really are.

There's no wonder that this game has spawned an entire genre of "Yume Nikki fangames" that ape the style and sometimes take the gameplay in bold new directions. Also unsurprising is just how fiery the fanbase can be in their love of it. If Yume Nikki clicks with you, it clicks. And it's wonderful.

EDIT: Originally, I had a warning here about how some technical issues this version of the game was running into. Most of those issues have been patched. The fact that Playism fixed these issues within a single day says a lot of good things about them, and about this Steam version of the game. Excellent job, guys. Back to the review...

Whether or not you're interested in this version or another, I can't possibly recommend Yume Nikki more. It's a gorgeous little gem that has always deserved more exposure than it got, and I hope you enjoy it.

Also, a gameplay suggestion: there is an adorable blonde girl somewhere in the game. If you turn the lights off and on enough, she'll give you something special!

And one more thing--this one a bit more serious. I, as somebody who has dealt with it in the past, find this game to be a great exploration of depression. That being said, certain events in this game may trigger people who have had much more serious bouts of depression or self-harm than me. If you're worried about that, I recommend doing a bit more research on the game before you bite into it.

39236512.review:
[b]What a weird timeline we live in.[/b]

Where to even [i]begin[/i] with Yume Nikki? Its hard to describe what the game is other than an exploration of dreams - yet its so much more than that by itself. Will I have to do Segments? It might be necessary. Lets go with that. But first, lemme get this out of the way.

[b]TL;DR[/b]: Yume Nikki is an exploration game about a young girl with Social aversion wandering around her dreams. The story has the consistency of a cloud, requiring player speculation. Lovely music, Lovely environments. [b][u]PLAY ON JP LANGUAGE (WITH ENGLISH PATCH(?)) AS CURRENT 'OFFICIAL' ENG TRANSLATION BREAKS SEVERAL SFX/MUSIC FILE CUES[/u][/b]

Now then.

[b]Story & Goal:[/b] The Story follows a Hikikomori/Social outcast named Madotsuki. Who hangs out in her room and spends her time doing what every other shut-in does - [strike]Video games & Shitposting[/strike] [b][i]Sleeping.[/i][/b] When she sleeps, she dreams. And Madotsuki is nothing if not a very, [i]very[/i] vivid lucid dreamer. A circle of doors to open up whole new worlds to Madotsuki, and the dangers that may lie in each one.

The goal of the game is to find all the games 24 - or so - effects and drop them off in the hub for the ending. And the Story? Well, uh. [b]There isn't one.[/b] Not directly, anyway. There's a lot of interesting characters and worlds you meet, some with their names too. But it doesn't actually tell you anything about madotsuki. Maybe some hints, maybe some themes that reoccur. But nothing concrete. So its no surprise things are up in the air and speculation is a foundation for the fandom.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] YN is an RPGMaker game. More specifically, one without RPGMaker 'combat.' You know what means? If you guessed walking simulator, You're right! The main elements of YN is exploration. Go here, to go there, to go there. This is offset by charming midi music and lovely spritework on the environments you visit, and fun FX that you have to collect to win the game. Not to mention the people you meet. Which brings me to my next note.

[b]Characters & Art:[/b] As I said before, nothing is actually explained to you besides basic game goal. And while you'll run into a lot of weird things as per dreams, there are a few stand-out characters. The Pianist Masada-Sensei. The sisters Monoe and Monoko, or the blonde island-dwelling Poniko who really doesn't like it when you touch her lightswitch. Maybe you'll get away with it once or twice, but dont press your luck. There's also of course the Toriningen. You'll know them when you see them, or more importantly when they see you.

Each stage presents it own, bizarre environment. From strange, maze-like disco territories to black and white Monochrome deserts. Not to mention strange squeaky stair fellows and colorful electronica monkeys. If you've played LSD, you'll feel right at home with the stranger cast of odd characters that aren't 'prominent.' And the music feels right and appropriate to each stage.

https://youtu.be/PwjOI6riH5s
https://youtu.be/O1MRNeKeUp0
(Save screen is also a good track, but I cant find one thats not an arrangement or doesnt have a spoiler art in the video. And yes, the ending does matter!)


[b]OVERALL:[/b] Yume Nikki is a game about wandering, collection, and learning about odd environments. The story throws itself at you like a box of incorrectly-matching Puzzle pieces with a rogue chess piece thrown in, but if you're the type that decides you need to cut and glue the pieces together with your own imagination: It might be for you! And the Fandom is always active with bits of art portraying their own interests, or humorous animation.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VyesXcoFOfA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UNhphyF74sA

Personally I hope YN showing up paves the way for other YN-esque games to show up. I really want an official steam listing for .flow.

39236485.review:
After over 13 years, Yume Nikki finally gets the Steam release that it deserves.

This game is among the most well-known games in the RPG Maker community (as it deserves), and has spawned countless amounts of fangames over time. This was my introductory step into both the surreal and horror genres of games, which are still my two most favorite genres to date, so I just had to give it my love now that it has a place on Steam.

The goal of this game is simple: Explore and find all of the Effects to unlock the ending. Along the way, take in the wide variety of scenery and visuals, and try to find hidden areas and secret events that are hidden throughout the different worlds. Use all of this information to make theories on what kind of person Madotsuki is and what kind of life she lives in, since the game is played entirely without dialogue or commentary outside of "you got an Effect" prompts.

If you like exploration, surreal imagery, and making theories on your own, I absolutely recommend playing this game. It does not cost a thing to play, but honestly, I was ready to spend money on it just to show my appreciation to the developer. I am keeping my fingers crossed in hopes that Yume 2kki, .flow, and other popular Yume Nikki fangames start getting Steam releases, as well.

Also, as a mysterious bonus... [url=https://promo.kadokawa.co.jp/gamecountdown/]keep an eye on this site[/url]. I do not know what this is about, but it looks like something big is being planned for this game.

[strike]I doubt that this is what will happen, but if they announce a Yume Nikki VR game, I will personally give my life and soul to Kikiyama as thanks.[/strike]

39235952.review:
A classic RPGMAKER exploration game, now on Steam? 
You play as Madotsuki, a mysterious girl who by sleeping in her bed can explore a surreal world of dreams. Inside the dream world are 'effects', each changing Madotsuki's appearance and giving her special abilities such as increasing her speed or allowing her to attack dream denizens. All of these effects (except one) can be acquired in any order. Upon collecting all of the effects, an ending can be triggered. The last update was released over 10 years ago, making this Steam release as mysterious and surreal as the game itself.

As of writing there is uncertainty of the developer's involvement in this release, and it seems to be released to promote a new game set to be announced ~2 weeks from now. The game has had other licensed adaptations such as a novel and manga, of which both have had mixed reception by the English community (as far as I've seen). 

Despite the mystery surrounding the author (who is known to us only by alias), the game has accrued a decent cult following over the years. You have probably seen characters from this game elsewhere. Over 250 fan games have been created by those inspired and intrigued by this experience (myself included).  
Other works have cited Yume Nikki as inspiration, such as Dreaming Sarah and Crypt Worlds. A common comparison is LSD: Dream Emulator, an older PlayStation game with a similar premise.

It is typically recommended to avoid walkthroughs and the wiki, and to explore the game thoroughly beforehand. It can take awhile to find every effect without outside assistance, and I myself followed a video walkthrough in learning how to complete the game. As such, I am mostly familiar only with content on the beaten path and have done minimal exploration outside of that. There are a lot of things to see in the dream world, I still come across things I have never seen before today. When showing the game to friends they typically explore for awhile before asking me to help guide them to the ending.

There are actually some good reasons to not approach the game completely blind. First of all, there is an effect that is relatively easy to obtain that increases Madotsuki's movement speed significantly. The catch is that the nexus, the first area accessed from Madotsuki's bedroom after sleeping, contains many doors leading to other areas of the dream world. You're supposed to pick one at random, but I will recommend the pink door at the bottom right to start with.

Another reason is that having the effects enhances exploration. There are some areas and events accessed/triggered by using certain effects. Given how vast the dream world is, it may be difficult to keep track of areas where an effect was needed to return to later.

I would recommend exploring the game blind, then looking at a walkthrough or outside source to assist in finding the remaining effects. As ideal as it would be to complete the game completely blind, the dream world is vast and some effects can be difficult to find. The wiki is very comprehensive, and the effects page simply says where the effect is rather than detailed instructions. 

An issue I have with the game are the near-empty looping maps. These areas aren't particularly interesting to explore, yet they usually have an effect somewhere in them. There is no in-game way of knowing where to go, and given the layout of these maps it is very possible to miss effects of areas you think you thoroughly explored. There is also a huge maze that I wouldn't blame anyone for looking up a map to.

I really enjoy the sounds present in the game, but I do take issue with some of the background music loops. There are some areas where I will mute the game, such as the block world (nexus door left of green).

Apparently this release is of an older version. I believe all of the content is here, but it is missing some bug fixes. There is some missing music and at least one crash I have encountered. You could go download the latest version online, but maybe this release will be updated.

Also, the game is technically incomplete? No one is expecting any updates at this point (last update being over 10 years ago), but it is worth keeping in mind that this may not have been the envisioned final product. 

Overall, I recommend trying this out. It isn't perfect and is fairly dated, but is certainly worth experiencing.

39235926.review:
After more than 13 years, it's finally on Steam.
Now, I was quite late getting into Yume Nikki myself (January 2017). I was aware of the game's existence and had been interested in it for a while but I couldn't be arsed to get it to work. Now, that issue is nonexistent. The game's originally in Japanese but the Steam version comes with an English patch built in, which also saves some time and hassle.
As for the game itself, it's a hit or miss. The gameplay is focused on exploring mysterious, cryptic worlds, finding "effects" in the meantime. These effects change your appearance and sometimes give you certain abilities. To beat the game, you have to find all 24.
The worlds are often quite confusing to navigate and it can take a long time to find something. Another issue is forgetting what leads where, as there's quite a bunch of places to go. If these things ever discourage you, just remember there's no shame in looking things up. There's a wiki that covers pretty much everything, and I'm sure there'll be some Steam guides on it as well now, if there aren't any already.
The soundtrack mostly consists of loops that last a few seconds. Though they can get a little repetitive over time they set the mood right. In my opinion it's fine the way it is, unless you get really lost you won't be hearing the same song for that long anyway.
The graphics are great, as long as you don't mind being able to count the pixels. The sprites aren't lazily thrown together, and every area has its own style which it sticks to.
Lastly, there's a handful of secrets hidden within this game, some harder to find than others. If you've (nearly) finished the game and feel like you've missed them, be sure to check those out before you finish.
If you enjoyed this game as much as I did and want more, there's a bunch of fangames out there which you could try out. My favorite is probably Yume 2kki, one organised and created by various users of 2ch. It has a lot of content and is being updated to this day, albeit with small additions at a time. I've spent over 45 hours playing it and nearly 100%ed it, so yeah.
Anyway, I hope this review was helpful. It's free, so even if you feel like it might not be something for you you can try it out for 10 minutes and check if that's really so.

39235595.review:
Hello dream world, my old friend.

More than ten years later, Yume Nikki has finally made it to Steam. Probably one of the best, most surreal horror adventure games that exist, a game able to both disturb and amaze at some of the sights and encounters without relying on underhanded tactics to do so. It also leaves much room for experimentation with the different 'effects' found ingame, some a bit more... pronounced than others. To say it all feels like a dream, or even a nightmare, would be putting it lightly - this is one of the only games to actually play out like one.

Yume Nikki is absolutely more than worth your time to explore, even for just a little bit at a time. The game is also completely free to download and enjoy, so the only thing you need to spend is a bit of your time. I wholeheartedly recommend playing with headphones and in the dark to really immerse yourself with the experience. It's had a big cult following for all these years for a reason, and you absolutely owe it to yourself to give it a try.

Also, the flute player's music is 11/10.

39234776.review:
A labyrinth of emotion and mystery, Yume Nikki starts off slow, but quickly becomes an incredibly intriguing escape. The world is large and interconnected, weaving into strange areas and looping back around again. Dark themes and unforgettable moments makes this game one of the greatest independent efforts ever to grace video games.

This Steam port is excellent. The team behind it has done a great job translating the game to English, and it runs great on Windows 10. Long gone are the days of having to use a locale emulator and several workarounds to get the game functioning. I'm so happy that it's finally accessible to a wider audience.

Overall, this is easily one of the best surrealist games ever made. It has a huge following for a reason, and numerous games owe a lot to it. Yume Nikki boasts one of the most memorable game worlds ever created, and its cryptic nature keeps you coming back for more. It lacks replay value, because your second playthrough won't be as magical as your first. However, it's worth playing to completion. Few games can match the level of mystery and emptiness that this game boasts.
